channel.title: Unsupervised learning on Hugo Cisneros
channel.description: Recent content in Unsupervised learning on Hugo Cisneros

item.title: Reservoir computing
item.description: tags Machine learning, Unconventional computing, Unsupervised learning Reservoir computing is a term used to describe a class of machine learning algorithms that rely on transient dynamics of a dynamical system to implement and manipulate goal-related information. The most famous example is echo-state networks, which uses random recurrent neural networks as reservoirs, but other dynamical systems can also be used. Reservoir computing with cellular automata Reservoir computing can use cellular automata as the reservoir.

item.title: Echo-state networks
item.description: tags Recurrent neural networks, Unsupervised learning resources Scholarpedia Principle An echo state network is usually a standard RNN with fixed random weights. The output from this RNN is used as a high dimensional feature map to be fed into a machine learning system. (Jaeger 2004; Jaeger, Maassand Principe 2007; Jaeger 2012) Bibliography Jaeger, H.. April 2, 2004. "Harnessing Nonlinearity: Predicting Chaotic Systems and Saving Energy in Wireless Communication". Science 304 (5667):78â€“80.
